key_points: Former US President Donald Trump acquitted on charge of incitement of insurrection related to the January 6 US Capitol riot.
US Senate vote was 57 to convict and 43 to acquit, falling short of the two-thirds needed for conviction.
Seven Republican senators voted to convict Trump, the largest number from an impeached president's own party in US history.
This was Trump's second impeachment trial, making him the only president to have been impeached twice.
Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer criticized the acquittal, implying that Republican senators chose Trump over the country.
Trump labeled the trial as 'the greatest witch hunt in the history of our Country'.
Democrats argued Trump incited the violence on January 6 through his false claims about election fraud.
Trump's defense denied incitement, claiming his speech was protected under free speech and dismissing the trial as political theatre.
The trial, lasting five days, was the fastest presidential impeachment trial in US history.
After the trial, divisions within the Republican Party were highlighted, especially between pro-Trump lawmakers and those advocating for accountability.
spokespersons: Michael van der Veen (One of Trump's lawyers)
